items.text: **Dru Samia**is a [[LINK|lang_en|Student_athlete|student athlete]] who plays for the [[LINK|lang_en|Oklahoma_Sooners_football|Oklahoma Sooners football]] team at [[LINK|lang_en|University_of_Oklahoma|University of Oklahoma]] . In November 2018, Samia was named as one of the three Big 12 Offensive Linemen of the Year by the [[LINK|lang_en|Big_12_Conference_football|Big 12 Conference]]. [[CITE|18|http://soonersports.com/ViewArticle.dbml?ATCLID=209874541&DB_OEM_ID=31000]] [[CITE|19|https://247sports.com/college/oklahoma/Article/Dru-Samia-one-of-three-Big-12-Offensive-Linemen-of-the-Year-125544686]] [[CITE|20|http://rohdeonsports.com/dru-samia]]

Dru Samia is of [[LINK|lang_en|Samoans|Samoan]] and [[LINK|lang_en|Caucasian_race|Caucasian]] ethnicity. He grew up in [[LINK|lang_en|Chinatown,_Sacramento|Sacramento, California]] in a football family. His father and two uncles played on the offensive line at [[LINK|lang_en|Southern_Oregon_University|Southern Oregon University]], where his uncle Gilbert was an all-conference selection in 1993. However Samia said growing up football wasn't talked about that much in the house. “It was never really prevalent,” Samia said of his father and uncles sharing football stories. “They didn’t make it a big deal around the house.” [[CITE|20|http://rohdeonsports.com/dru-samia]]
Growing up, Samia spent most of his time with his mother and two sisters.
“There were really a lot of girls in the house,” said Samia, whose father, Drury, worked the night shift and rested during the day.
Samia had no brothers, so his uncle, Gilbert, filled the role.
“He was kind of like an older brother to me,” Samia said of Gilbert.

“He was someone to hang out with, talk [[LINK|lang_en|Video_game|video games]] and [[LINK|lang_en|sport|sports]] with. He definitely was the main factor in what got me here.” [[CITE|20|http://rohdeonsports.com/dru-samia]] Samia started practicing football and doing workouts with his uncle Gilbert in high school. He really fell in love with football when he started playing for his high school football team in his [[LINK|lang_en|Freshman|freshman]] year. [[CITE|20|http://rohdeonsports.com/dru-samia]]

While playing football for [[LINK|lang_en|River_Valley_High_School_(California)|River Valley High School]], Dru Samia was ranked by Rivals, Scout and [[LINK|lang_en|247sports|247Sports]] as a four-star recruit and by [[LINK|lang_en|ESPN|ESPN]] as a three-star recruit. He was recognized as No. 136 player overall nationally by Scout. Samia was rated as No. 13 offensive tackle in the United States according to Scout and No. 23 according to Rivals. He was slotted as No. 14 offensive guard in country by Scout, No. 44 by 247Sports and No. 59 by ESPN. Samia was chosen as No. 21 player in state of California by Scout, No. 38 by Rivals, No. 56 by 247Sports and No. 93 by ESPN. He was ranked 136th in West Region by ESPN and invited to The Opening showcase event. Samia joined the [[LINK|lang_en|Oklahoma_Sooners_football|Oklahoma Sooners football]] team at [[LINK|lang_en|University_of_Oklahoma|University of Oklahoma]] after receiving offers from [[LINK|lang_en|University_of_California,_Los_Angeles|UCLA]], [[LINK|lang_en|Arizona_State_University|Arizona State University]], [[LINK|lang_en|Texas_Tech_University|Texas Tech University]], and [[LINK|lang_en|University_of_California,_Berkeley|University of California, Berkeley]]. [[CITE|-1|http://soonersports.com/ViewArticle.dbml?DB_OEM_ID=31000&%3BATCLID=209874541]] [[CITE|21|https://thefootballbrainiacs.com/breaking-dru-samia-commits-to-oklahoma]]
